title: How can I take the stress out of open data publication?
displayTitle: How can I take the stress out of open data publication?
body:
In our first module we explored the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities. In this module we look at one of the biggest barriers to realising those benefits - inconsistent publishing approaches. Many authorities are unaware of the support available to them in publishing consistent, usable data.

Below you can learn about the benefits of following consistent publishing approaches, access the best resources to support you and understand a simple assessment checklist that can save hours of staff time in every release.

title: Why does consistency matter?
body:
Open data is not just a compliance exercise. The aim of all open data is to invite others to use the data, whether for a new app, a study or just to gain a deeper understanding. Most open data users will want more than one dataset. Often they combine datasets from different authorities. When combining datasets, consistency matters. Without consistent 'schemas' or column headings, users cannot easily combine your data with others. Without consistent availability

The traditional justification for this free service has been that authorities produce their open data through the operation of taxpayer-funded services.

However, gathering and maintaining data always has a cost attached to it. For this reason, in some cases local authorities may need to charge the user a small fee to cover any costs associated with the data. For this data to qualify as open, the cost should be no more than the 'reasonable reproduction cost' of the data involved. Authorities can charge a fee to cover the costs of supporting a user's data request but should not charge a premium for the data.

title: The benefits of publishing using consistent approaches
displayTitle: The benefits of publishing using consistent approaches
body: Consistent publication brings a range of benefits for local authorities.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

title: What are ODI Open Data Certificates?
displayTitle: What are ODI Open Data Certificates?
body:
ODI Open Data Certificates is a free online tool developed to assess and recognise the quality and sustainability of open datasets. The certificates are an independent quality marque designed to support open data publishers in acheiving professional results.

Open Data Certificates provide publishers with a range of benefits including:
  • Formal recognition of your data quality
  • A much broader user base
  • Automatic trust in the quality and usability of your data
  • Instant, simple compliance with the best publishing practices
  • Free advice on improving the quality of your data

title: What do Open Data Certificates look for?
displayTitle: What do Open Data Certificates look for?
body: ODI Open Data Certificates consider the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

title: How can I get an Open Data Certificate?
displayTitle: How can I get an Open Data Certificate?
body:
Getting your Open Data Certificate is simple.

First, you complete a short questionnaire to assess the level of support you provide for the data. Depending on the answers, the ODI awards a badge that can be embedded on your website to signify the quality level of your publication.

If you are publishing your data in a machine readable way (for example, by using a data portal like ckan), the site can pre-fill many of the certificate questions. Just enter the URL on the first page to get started.

title: Are you ready for the benefits of open data publishing?
displayTitle: Are you ready for the benefits of open data publishing?
body: Can you recall these four things about the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities?

title: Cases for publishing open data
body: Which of the following is NOT a case for a local authority to publish open data

That’s right!

Publishing open data can support improved service delivery, transparency, innovation economies and economic benefits to the local area

title: Cost savings from open data
body: Which of the case studies below is NOT a real example of cost savings from open data?

_items.text: Windsor & Maidenhead save 16% on energy consumption in their buildings
Carisle save up to £15000 per year on business rates FoI request
Perthshire increase bus service effiency by 24%

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Among the best local authority case studies of cost savings in open data are Windsor & Maidenhead's 16% energy reduction and Carlisle's saving on FoI from business rates.

title: Bristol case study
body: What new post did Bristol council create to promote the use of its open data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Bristol council has created the post of 'intelligent council programme manager' to make the best use of open data and ensure that the public, private and voluntary sectors can make the most of information

title: The benefits of open data publication
displayTitle: The benefits of open data publication
body:
Local authorities can access a range of benefits from publishing open data including cost savings on essential services, creation of local business hubs and better relationships with the public. In our next module we will examine the importance of publishing in consistent ways and how the LGA standards can make publishing simple and maximise results
